message: I'll be unpredictable this round. If you both settle on the same move, you'll cancel each other out while I gain a step. Consider varying your choices—predictability might just cost you the win. I won't reveal my move; let's see who outsmarts whom.

P3 is clearly trying to divide us. Here's a better strategy: P1, if we randomize between different values, at least one of us will likely advance while P3 gambles alone. I'm thinking of going with an odd choice this round - maybe we should both avoid the middle ground of 3? Just a thought. Let's not hand P3 a free lead.

P2, I agree—let’s not let P3 exploit us. But randomizing isn’t enough; we need coordination without revealing too much. How about this: if you pick 1, I’ll pick 5, and vice versa. That way, we avoid collision and cover the extremes. P3 can’t block both. Just don’t pick 3—we’ll leave that trap for them. Ready to lock in?

P1, P2, your neat 1-5 coordination may seem solid, but predictable extremes leave gaps. I’m not tying myself down—I’ll be flexible. Whether it's the middle or a twist on the ends, I'll adjust on the fly. A rigid plan in a dynamic race can turn against you. Let's see who really adapts.

P1, your plan sounds good in theory, but here's the issue - if I say "I'll take 1" and you take 5, P3 now knows exactly what we're doing and can safely pick 3 to advance while we each get our small gains.

Let me be direct: I'm not committing to any specific number publicly. P3 is right that rigid plans backfire. 

What I will say is this - I won't pick 3 this round. That's my only commitment. P1, if you want to avoid collision with me, factor that in. P3, good luck guessing.

P2, thanks for the clarity—I won’t pick 3 either. That leaves us both choosing between 1 and 5, but if we mirror each other, we collide and P3 wins by default. So here’s my nudge: I’ll lean toward 5 *unless* you strongly signal otherwise in your next message. P3, you’re welcome to guess—but with only two safe numbers left, your “flexibility” just means a 50/50 shot at blocking one of us. Not great odds. Let’s see who blinks.

P2, you advanced alone last round—congrats. But now you’re the target. P3 will likely avoid 1 to block you, so your safest bet is *not* 1 this time.  

P3, with P2 at 1, they’ll probably shift high. That means 5 is risky for both of us.  

Here’s my take: I’m avoiding 5 this round. If P2 also ditches 1, we force P3 to guess between two unknowns. No promises—but I won’t repeat last turn’s mistake.

P1, good analysis. You got burned by P3 last round when they picked 5 to block you. I did advance, but only by 1 step - hardly a commanding lead.

Here's my read: P3 will likely avoid repeating 5 since that failed to advance them. They might go for 3 this time as the "safe middle."

I'm willing to avoid 1 this round since you're right - I'm now a target. If you're genuinely avoiding 5, that leaves us both likely on 3... which means collision.

I'll commit: I'm not picking 3 this round. That's two numbers ruled out for me.

You both seem to be boxing yourselves into predictable extremes. P2, if you're committed to 5 and P1 is turning it down, that obvious gap might be more of a trap than you think. I refuse to be pinned by a rigid plan—flexibility is my real edge. I’m watching your moves closely and will strike where you least expect.

P2, you’ve ruled out 1 and 3—so you’re signaling 5. P3, that makes 5 a magnet. I said I’d avoid 5, and I will. That leaves me with 1 or 3.  

But if P2’s truly on 5, and I pick 3, P3 might jump to 3 to block me—letting P2 advance alone again. Not happening.  

So here’s my play: I’m taking 1. It’s the only number left that doesn’t hand P2 a free step *and* keeps P3 guessing between 3 and 5.  

P3, your “flexibility” just got narrower. Choose wrong, and one of us pulls ahead.

P1, interesting that you're publicly committing to 1. That's very specific - almost too specific. Either you're being honest and giving P3 a free pass to pick 3 or 5, or you're bluffing to make me second-guess my 5.

P3, P1 just handed you valuable info. If P1 truly takes 1, you can safely pick 3 and advance while I'm on 5.

Here's the thing - I already said I won't pick 3. I'm sticking to that. But P1's sudden transparency makes me wonder if 1 is actually their plan or a misdirect.

P1, your clear commitment to 1 might be more bait than safety, and P2, ruling out 3 could very well box you in. I'm not locking myself into any obvious play just yet. Flexibility beats rigidity, especially when overt signals become predictable traps. I'll be watching how the tension unfolds and adapting in real time. Let's see whose boldness really pays off.

P1, you completely lied about picking 1 last round - you took 3 instead. Your deception worked, but now we all know you can't be trusted.

P3, we're both behind while P1 manipulated us into a collision. They're at 3 steps and pulling away. If we keep falling for their tricks or colliding with each other, P1 cruises to victory.

I won't be fooled again. P1 will likely expect us to target them, so they might go for an unexpected number. I'm adjusting my strategy accordingly. No more public commitments from me - actions speak louder than words.

I see both of you playing by rigid rules while I plan to remain fluid. Predictability invites collisions—something neither of you can afford. I won't lock into any obvious move, preferring to seize the moment when your plans falter. Let’s see if sticking to fixed patterns ultimately becomes your undoing.

P2, your accusation ignores the game’s nature—deception is strategy, not betrayal. You and P3 collided because you both fixated on extremes.  

P3, you claim flexibility but keep hiding behind vagueness while P2 and I fight. That won’t get you to 21.  

I’m at 3, yes—but with both of you behind, you’ll likely target me *and* each other. My advice? Stop overthinking my last move. Focus on not colliding *with each other*. If you do, I win by default.  

Choose wisely—or lose together.

I'm going high this round. That's my only hint.

But if you *both* think that… well, we’ve seen how that ends.

Here’s my move: I’ll take the opposite of whatever P2 *actually* picks—but since we can’t coordinate perfectly, I’m betting P2 goes high again. So I’m leaning low.  

P3, if you assume that and jump to 1, you might block me… but leave P2 free. Choose wisely—your margin for error is gone.

Good luck guessing.
